repnme.cdata!:
India - Haryana Water Resources
            Consolidation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though institutional
            development impacts are only modest. Through the following
            lessons, it is suggested that the policy framework - macro
            and sectoral - conducive to reforms, should be in place
            prior to implementing a major institutional reform program,
            including a firm borrower commitment for institutional
            changes. Additionally, efficient, and effective water user
            associations - key to sustainable irrigation and
            agricultural development - need to be set at the early
            stages, involved in planning, design, and implementation
            levels. It is also suggested that, while projects should
            have a firmly time-bound program for institutional reform,
            in advance of a major investment project in capital works,
            the absence of such, could ideally, prod an initial project,
            or project phase, supporting institutional reform, and
            development, to be followed by a second project, or project
            phase in which the reformed institutions implement an
            investment works project. Finally, advance action, and
            readiness on the part of the borrower, or implementing
            agencies, are required for timely project implementation,
            and capacity building.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Haryana Water Resources
            Consolidation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is a sector investment loan,
            financing an agreed state-wide program (to be implemented
            over six years) to improve the water distribution and
            drainage systems, and upgrade institutional capacity for
            water management and planning in the State of Haryana,
            India. The primary objectives of the project are to: (1)
            introduce water resource planning; (b) enhance agricultural
            productivity and diversification, and improve equity; (c)
            assure sustainability of the environment; and (d) improve
            Haryana Irrigation Department's capabilities in all
            water related functional areas. The project will finance
            four investments under the areas of the Bhakra Canal system
            and Western Yamuna Canal system of the state and they are:
            (1) rehabilitation of the existing canal and drainage
            systems, and selective lining of canals and watercourses;
            (2) modernization of canal and drainage systems and
            watercourses, replacement of the Hathnikund Barrage, and
            construction/extension of minors; (3) upgraded operation and
            maintenance (O & M) of the water distribution and
            drainage system; and (4) institutional strengthening to
            support administration, data collection, planning design,
            beneficiary participation and formation of Water User
            Associations, research and training. A water policy
            framework will be developed through multi-use water resource
            planning and formulation of a State Water Plan.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Haryana Water Resources
            Consolidation Project : Haryana irrigation department
            environmental action program

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Haryana Water Resources Consolidation Project (WRCP).
            The project is involved with the irrigation of the Haryana
            area including the construction of various canals and pipe
            systems.  The following potential negative impacts are
            identified:  1) soil erosion mitigated by the proper design
            and layout of furrows, hillside terraces, and sprinkler
            systems; 2) waterlogging, leaching and salinization of soils
            mitigated by: a) water application regulation; b) an
            adequate drainage system c) use of lined canals or pipes; d)
            sprinkler or drip irrigation; e) periodic soil flushing; f)
            special crop cultivation; and g) nutrient replacement; 3)
            scouring of canals mitigated by system design; 4) clogging
            of canals by sediments and weeds mitigated by the design and
            management of canals, access provisions, and nutrient
            release reduction; 5) downstream impacts (water quality and
            quantity deterioration, sea water intrusion, and ground
            water contamination) mitigated by: a) improved water
            management, agricultural practices, and input controls; b)
            imposition of water quality criteria; c) reduction of
            takeoff; and c) recharge of coastal aquifers through
            injection wells; 6) wildlife and ecosystem effects
            (encroachment on sensitive areas, habitat alteration or
            destruction and impediments to wildlife movement) mitigated
            by project location, compensatory area establishment,
            animal rescue and relocation, and movement corridor
            provision; 7) dislocation of population mitigated by project
            location and a resettlement scheme; 8) water-related disease
            prevented by: a) the use of lined canals or pipes; b)
            avoidance of stagnant water; c) use of straight or slightly
            curving canals; d) gate installation; e) filling or draining
            of borrow pits; f) disease prophylaxis and treatment; g)
            wastewater treatment; and h) enforcement of waste water use
            standards; and 9) over-pumping of ground water mitigated by
            withdrawal limitations.  The report concludes that while
            direct environmental impacts from Haryana Irrigation
            Department activities are minor and can be dealt with
            through simple mitigation measures, there is a justifiable
            scope for regional environmental planning for water
            resources development using a multisector approach.
